title: Central Bank Counterfeit Deterrence Group
text:
The mission of the Central Bank Counterfeit Deterrence Group (CBCDG) (originally designated as Special Study Group 2 or SSG-2 of the <a href="Group%20of%20Ten%20%28economic%201962%29">G10</a>) is to investigate emerging threats to the security of <a href="banknote">banknote</a>s and to propose solutions for implementation by issuing authorities. The CBCDG is a <a href="working%20group">working group</a> of 27 <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a>s and note printing authorities, and is chaired by <a href="Thomas%20Jordan%20%28economist%29">Thomas Jordan</a>, the chairman of the <a href="Swiss%20National%20Bank">Swiss National Bank</a>. 
The CBCDG maintains a web site designed to advise the public about national laws related to the reproduction of banknotes.
In 2004, CBCDG announced the development of a "<a href="Counterfeit%20Deterrence%20System">Counterfeit Deterrence System</a>" (CDS) incorporating a technical means for the detection of banknotes. This system was reportedly developed by the U.S.-based <a href="digital%20watermark">watermark</a> technology company <a href="Digimarc">Digimarc</a>. 
<a href="Adobe%20Systems">Adobe Systems</a> was subsequently the subject of controversy in when it was revealed that the firm had voluntarily adopted the CDS in <a href="Adobe%20Photoshop">Adobe Photoshop</a>, preventing Photoshop from processing some images of currency. Jasc (publisher of <a href="Paint%20Shop%20Pro">Paint Shop Pro</a>) and Adobe stated that they had implemented CDS; they reportedly did not receive technical details of the CDS <a href="algorithm">algorithm</a> (in other words, it was provided to them as a <a href="Black%20box%20%28systems%29">black box</a>). Some artists and professional graphic designers suggested that the CDS would make it more difficult for them to use Photoshop to produce images that used currency in lawful ways. <a href="Steven%20J.%20Murdoch">Steven J. Murdoch</a> has begun a technical investigation of how the CDS works.
